<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Net Sales
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Consolidated Net Sales.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated net sales increased by $80.8&nbsp;million, or 2.2%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the
	fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. Company-operated Sally Beauty Supply and BSG stores that have been open for 14&nbsp;months or longer contributed an increase in consolidated net sales of
	approximately $98.7&nbsp;million, or 2.6% of consolidated net sales. Other sales channels (including sales from stores that have been open for less than 14&nbsp;months, incremental sales from
	businesses acquired in the preceding 12&nbsp;months, sales through our BSG franchise-based businesses and distributor sales consultants, and sales from our Sally Beauty Supply non-store sales
	channels) in the aggregate experienced a net decrease in sales of approximately $17.9&nbsp;million, or 0.5% of consolidated net sales, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014,
	primarily due to fewer acquisitions and store openings, and softer Sally Beauty Supply non-store sales. Consolidated net sales for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, are inclusive of a
	net negative
	impact from changes in foreign currency exchange rates of $87.3&nbsp;million, or 2.3% of consolidated net sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, consolidated net sales reflect a same store sales growth rate of 2.9% compared to 2.0% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. For the
	fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, our consolidated same store sales growth rate was positively impacted by improved customer traffic in our BSG segment in the U.S. For the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2014, the consolidated same store sales growth rate was negatively impacted by lower traffic in both operating segments driven primarily by inclement weather in the U.S.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	$80.8&nbsp;million increase in consolidated net sales is primarily the result of increases in unit volume (including increases in sales at existing stores and the incremental sales from 145
	company-operated stores opened or acquired during the last twelve months) and average unit prices (resulting from changes in product mix, including the impact on average unit prices of third-party
	brands introduced this year at both segments).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Sally Beauty Supply.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net sales for Sally Beauty Supply increased by $20.8&nbsp;million, or 0.9% of segment net sales, for the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. In the Sally Beauty Supply segment, company-operated stores that have been open for 14&nbsp;months or longer
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	59
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=63,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1014287,FOLIO='59',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DQ10401A.;6',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='10-NOV-2016;19:31' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ10401_1_60">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	contributed
	an increase in segment net sales of approximately $30.0&nbsp;million, or 1.3% of segment net sales. Other sales channels (including sales from stores that have been open for less than
	14&nbsp;months and sales from our non-store sales channels, which include the catalog and e-commerce sales of our Sinelco Group subsidiaries) in the aggregate experienced a net decrease in sales of
	approximately $9.2&nbsp;million, or 0.4% of segment net sales, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily due to fewer Sally Beauty Supply store openings and softer
	non-store sales. Net sales for Sally Beauty Supply for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, are inclusive of a net negative impact from changes in foreign currency exchange rates of
	approximately $70.9&nbsp;million, or 3.1% of Sally Beauty Supply's net sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, the Sally Beauty Supply segment's net sales reflect a same store sales growth rate of 1.7% compared to 1.3% for the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2014. For the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, the Sally Beauty Supply segment's same store sales growth rate was positively impacted by higher average sales
	transaction amounts at our U.S. stores compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. For the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, the segment's same
	store sales growth rate was adversely impacted by lower traffic driven primarily by inclement weather in the U.S.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	$20.8&nbsp;million increase in the Sally Beauty Supply segment's net sales is the result of increases in unit volume (including increases in sales at existing stores and the incremental sales
	from 111 company-operated stores opened during the last twelve months) and average unit prices (resulting from changes in product mix, including the impact on average unit prices of third-party brands
	introduced this year at our Sally Beauty Supply segment).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Beauty Systems Group.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net sales for BSG increased by $60.1&nbsp;million, or 4.2% of segment net sales, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015,
	compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. In the BSG segment, company-operated stores that have been open for 14&nbsp;months or longer contributed an increase in segment net sales
	of approximately $68.7&nbsp;million, or 4.8% of segment net sales, and sales through our distributor sales consultants contributed an increase in segment net sales of approximately
	$9.1&nbsp;million, or 0.6%, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, while sales from stores that have been open for less than 14&nbsp;months experienced a decrease of
	$11.0&nbsp;million, or 0.8% of segment net sales, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily due to a shift in the timing of store openings in the normal course of BSG's
	business. Other sales channels (including sales through our franchise-based businesses and incremental sales from businesses acquired in the preceding 12&nbsp;months) in the aggregate experienced a
	net decrease in sales of approximately $6.7&nbsp;million, or 0.5% of segment net sales, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily due to fewer acquisitions. Net sales
	for BSG for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, are inclusive of a net negative impact from changes in foreign currency exchange rates of approximately $16.5&nbsp;million, or 1.1% of
	BSG's net sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, the BSG segment's net sales reflect a same store sales growth rate of 5.7% compared to 3.5% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014.
	For the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, the BSG segment's same store sales growth rate was positively impacted by improved customer traffic in the U.S. compared to the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	$60.1&nbsp;million increase in the BSG segment's net sales is primarily the result of increases in unit volume (including increases in sales at existing stores and the incremental sales from 34
	company-operated stores opened or acquired during the last twelve months) and average unit prices (resulting from changes in product mix, including the impact of certain third-party brands with higher
	average unit prices introduced this year at our BSG segment).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gross Profit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Consolidated Gross Profit.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated gross profit increased by $37.7&nbsp;million, or 2.0%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to
	the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily due to higher net sales. Consolidated gross profit as a percentage of net sales, or consolidated gross profit margin, was 49.5% for the
	fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to 49.6% for the fiscal year ended
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	60
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=64,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=290497,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DQ10401A.;6',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='10-NOV-2016;19:31' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ10401_1_61">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	September&nbsp;30,
	2014. Consolidated gross profit for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 is inclusive of a negative impact from changes in foreign currency exchange rates of
	approximately $40.6&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Sally Beauty Supply.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sally Beauty Supply's gross profit increased by $10.7&nbsp;million, or 0.8%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared
	to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily due to higher sales. Sally Beauty Supply's gross profit as a percentage of net sales was 54.8% for both the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2015 and the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. Sally Beauty Supply's gross profit for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 is inclusive of a negative impact
	from changes in foreign currency exchange rates of approximately $33.4&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Beauty Systems Group.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BSG's gross profit increased by $26.9&nbsp;million, or 4.5%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the fiscal
	year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, due to higher sales and improved gross profit margin. BSG's gross profit as a percentage of net sales was 41.3% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30,
	2015, compared to 41.1% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. BSG's gross profit for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 is inclusive of a negative impact from changes in
	foreign currency exchange rates of approximately $7.2&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Consolidated selling, general and administrative expenses increased by $39.6&nbsp;million, or 3.1%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015,
	compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This increase was attributable in part to incremental expenses (including employee compensation, rent and other occupancy-related expenses)
	resulting from stores opened in the preceding 12&nbsp;months (approximately 145 net additional company-operated stores added since September&nbsp;30, 2014, which represents a 3.1% increase in the
	number of stores). In addition, the increase reflects higher recruitment and compensation-related expenses primarily in connection with our ongoing management transition plans (approximately
	$5.0&nbsp;million), higher expenses related to on-going upgrades to our information technology systems (approximately $3.7&nbsp;million), higher advertising costs in our Sally Beauty Supply
	segment (approximately $5.4&nbsp;million) and higher expenses principally associated with store remodels and relocations (approximately $2.4&nbsp;million) in the Sally Beauty Supply segment,
	higher corporate expenses related to the data security incidents and to ongoing data security upgrades (approximately $4.0&nbsp;million, net of related insurance recovery), and expenses incurred in
	connection with the restructuring of our Sally Beauty Supply segment's operations in Germany of approximately $3.9&nbsp;million ($5.3&nbsp;million, net of approximately $1.4&nbsp;million
	reflected in cost of products sold and distribution expenses) in the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015. Selling, general and administrative expenses, as a percentage of net sales, increased
	to 34.2% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to 33.9% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, mainly as a result of the expense increases mentioned earlier in
	this paragraph. Consolidated selling, general and administrative expenses for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 are inclusive of a net positive impact from changes in foreign currency
	exchange rates, of approximately $34.2&nbsp;million, resulting from a stronger U.S. dollar during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Depreciation and Amortization
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Consolidated depreciation and amortization increased by $9.7&nbsp;million, or 12.2%, to $89.4&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30,
	2015, compared to $79.7&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This increase reflects the incremental depreciation and amortization expenses associated with capital
	expenditures made in the preceding 12&nbsp;months (mainly in connection with store openings in both operating segments, store remodels in the Sally Beauty Supply segment in the U.S., and ongoing
	information technology upgrades), partially offset by the impact of assets (including intangible assets) that became fully depreciated (or fully amortized) in the preceding 12&nbsp;months.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	61
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Consolidated
	operating earnings decreased by $11.7&nbsp;million, or 2.3%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This
	decrease is primarily the result of higher unallocated expenses and a decrease in our Sally Beauty Supply segment's operating earnings, partially offset by an increase in our BSG segment's operating
	earnings and lower share-based compensation expense, as discussed below. Operating earnings, as a percentage of net sales, decreased to 12.9% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015,
	compared to 13.5% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This decrease reflects higher consolidated operating expenses as a percentage of consolidated net sales, including incremental
	corporate expenses related primarily to the data security incidents and ongoing data security upgrades of approximately $4.0&nbsp;million (net of certain insurance recovery related to the data
	security incidents) and expenses of $5.3&nbsp;million related to the Sally Beauty Supply segment's Germany restructuring mentioned earlier.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Sally Beauty Supply.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sally Beauty Supply's segment operating earnings decreased by $19.3&nbsp;million, or 4.5%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30,
	2015, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. The decrease in the Sally Beauty Supply segment's operating earnings was primarily a result of the incremental costs related to 111
	additional company-operated stores (stores opened during the past twelve months) operating during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015. In addition, the decrease reflects higher advertising
	costs ($5.4&nbsp;million), the incremental depreciation expense ($4.8&nbsp;million) associated with capital expenditures made in the preceding 12&nbsp;months (mainly in connection with store
	openings in several geographies and store remodels in the U.S., and with ongoing information technology upgrades), expenses related to the Germany restructuring initiative ($5.3&nbsp;million),
	higher expenses principally associated with store remodels and relocations ($2.4&nbsp;million) and higher recruitment and employee compensation-related expenses in connection with our management
	transition plans ($1.4&nbsp;million), partially offset by the increase in the Sally Beauty Supply segment's net sales described above. Segment operating earnings, as a percentage of net sales,
	decreased to 17.7% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to 18.7% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This decrease reflects higher segment operating expenses
	as a percentage of the segment's net sales, primarily as a result of the expense increases mentioned earlier in this paragraph.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Beauty Systems Group.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BSG's segment operating earnings increased by $14.2&nbsp;million, or 6.5%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to
	the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily as a result of increased sales, partially offset by the incremental costs related to 34 additional
	company-operated stores (stores opened during the past twelve months) operating during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, as well as by the incremental depreciation expense
	($1.9&nbsp;million) associated with
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	62
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">

<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	capital
	expenditures made in the preceding 12&nbsp;months (mainly in connection with ongoing information technology upgrades), higher allowance for doubtful accounts receivable (approximately
	$0.8&nbsp;million, predominantly related to one customer) and higher expenses related primarily to upgrades to our BSG information technology systems (approximately $0.7&nbsp;million). Segment
	operating earnings, as a percentage of net sales, increased to 15.4% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to 15.0% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014,
	primarily as a result of the increase in the segment's gross profit margin described above, as well as a reduction in the segment's operating expenses as a percentage of the segment's net sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Unallocated Expenses.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unallocated expenses, which represent certain corporate costs (such as payroll, employee benefits and travel expenses for corporate staff,
	certain professional fees, certain new business development expenses and corporate governance expenses) that have not been charged to our operating segments, increased by $11.9&nbsp;million, or
	10.0%, for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This increase was due primarily to higher recruitment and employee
	compensation-related expenses primarily in connection with our ongoing management transition plans (approximately $3.2&nbsp;million), incremental depreciation expense ($3.3&nbsp;million)
	associated with capital expenditures made in the preceding 12&nbsp;months (mainly in connection with ongoing information technology upgrades), higher corporate expenses related primarily to on-going
	upgrades to our information technology systems (approximately $2.5&nbsp;million), higher corporate expenses related primarily to the data security incidents and ongoing data security upgrades
	(approximately $4.0&nbsp;million, net of certain insurance recovery related to the data security incidents) and higher professional fees primarily related to new business development and other
	corporate initiatives (approximately $1.0&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Share-based Compensation Expense.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total compensation costs charged against income for share-based compensation arrangements decreased by $5.3&nbsp;million, or
	24.1%, to $16.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to $22.1&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This decrease was mainly due
	to lower aggregate fair value at the date of grant of the stock options awarded during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 and the impact of awards that became fully vested since
	September&nbsp;30, 2014. In addition, this decrease reflects the impact of a $3.5&nbsp;million stock options award in connection with the executive management transition plan during the fiscal
	year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, without a comparable award in the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Interest Expense
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Interest expense was $116.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to $116.3&nbsp;million the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2014. Interest expense is net of interest income of approximately $0.2&nbsp;million for each of the fiscal years ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 and 2014. The increase in
	interest expense was primarily attributable to the effect of higher principal balances on our debt outstanding during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, including the senior notes due
	2023 issued in October 2013. This increase was partially offset by lower borrowings under the ABL facility during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2014. Please see Note&nbsp;13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements in Item&nbsp;8
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&#151;
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	"Financial
	Statements and Supplementary Data" contained elsewhere in this Annual Report and "Liquidity and Capital Resources" below for additional information about the Company's debt.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Provision for Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The provision for income taxes was $143.4&nbsp;million and $144.7&nbsp;million and the annual effective tax rate was 37.9% and 37.0% for the fiscal years
	ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 and 2014, respectively. The increase in the effective income tax rate for the fiscal year 2015, compared to the fiscal year 2014, is primarily due to increased foreign
	tax losses resulting in part from our ongoing expansion into international geographies and a beneficial tax settlement in the fiscal year 2014 without a comparable tax benefit in the fiscal year 2015.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Net Earnings
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As a result of the foregoing, consolidated net earnings decreased by $10.9&nbsp;million, or 4.4%, to $235.1&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to $246.0&nbsp;million for
	the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. Net earnings, as a percentage of net sales, were 6.1% for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to 6.6% for the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Financial Condition
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	September&nbsp;30, 2016 Compared to September&nbsp;30, 2015
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Working capital (current assets less current liabilities) decreased by $11.2&nbsp;million to $684.2&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to
	$695.4&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015. The ratio of current assets to current liabilities was 2.40 to 1.00 at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to 2.41 to 1.00 at September&nbsp;30,
	2015. The decrease in working capital reflects a decrease in current assets of $14.3&nbsp;million, partially offset by a decrease in current liabilities of $3.0&nbsp;million. The decrease in
	current assets is principally due to a decrease in cash and cash equivalents of $53.4&nbsp;million (please see "Liquidity and Capital Resources" below for a description of our sources and uses of
	cash) and a decrease of $5.4&nbsp;million in accounts receivable, other, partially offset by an increase of $22.1&nbsp;million in inventory, an increase in other current assets of
	$17.8&nbsp;million and an increase in deferred income tax assets of $6.3&nbsp;million. The decrease in current liabilities is principally due to a decrease of $4.5&nbsp;million in accounts
	payable and a decrease in income taxes payable of $4.3&nbsp;million, partially offset by an increase of $5.9&nbsp;million in accrued liabilities, as discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Accounts
	receivable, other decreased by $5.4&nbsp;million to $37.0&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $42.5&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 due primarily to the
	timing of collections from customers and vendors in the ordinary course of our business and the impact of foreign currency translation adjustments. Inventory increased by $22.1&nbsp;million to
	$907.3&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $885.2&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 primarily due to the effect of stores opened (145 net additional Sally Beauty Supply
	and BSG company-operated stores added during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016) and the addition of new product lines in both operating segments, partially offset by the impact of
	foreign currency translation adjustments of approximately $12.5&nbsp;million. Other current assets increased by $17.8&nbsp;million to $54.9&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to
	$37.0&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 due primarily to an increase in income tax receivable in the ordinary course of our business. Deferred income tax assets increased by
	$6.3&nbsp;million to $40.0&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $33.7&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 due primarily to the timing of recognition, for financial
	accounting purposes, of the loss contingency obligation discussed earlier compared to the timing of recognition of such loss for income tax purposes. Please see Note&nbsp;16 of notes to consolidated
	financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Accounts
	payable decreased by $4.5&nbsp;million to $271.4&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $275.9&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 due to the timing of payments to
	suppliers primarily in connection with recent purchases of merchandise inventory and capital expenditures. Accrued liabilities increased by $5.9&nbsp;million to $214.6&nbsp;million at
	September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $208.7&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015, primarily due to an increase of $12.8&nbsp;million in the loss contingency obligation in connection with
	the data security incidents and an increase in other operational accruals, partially offset by a decrease in accrued compensation and benefits of $5.6&nbsp;million and a decrease in interest payable
	in connection with our debt, mainly as a result of our December 2015 debt refinancing. Income taxes payable decreased by $4.3&nbsp;million to $2.0&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016,
	compared to $6.3&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 due primarily to the timing of federal estimated income tax payments in the ordinary course of our business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net
	property and equipment increased by $48.7&nbsp;million to $319.6&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $270.8&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015, primarily due to
	capital expenditures of $143.4&nbsp;million, including
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>

</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	amounts
	incurred but not paid, partially offset by the fiscal year 2016 depreciation expense of $86.3&nbsp;million and foreign currency translation adjustments of approximately $5.9&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Goodwill
	increased by $8.3&nbsp;million to $532.7&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $524.4&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015, primarily due to $12.8&nbsp;million
	of goodwill recorded in connection with businesses acquired during the fiscal year 2016, partially offset by foreign currency translation adjustments of approximately $4.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Intangible
	assets, excluding goodwill, decreased by $5.9&nbsp;million to $93.0&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $98.8&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015, primarily
	due to amortization expense of $13.3&nbsp;million recognized in the fiscal year 2016 and foreign currency translation adjustments, partially offset by $10.1&nbsp;million of intangible assets
	recorded in connection with businesses acquired during the fiscal year 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Long-term
	debt, including current portion, decreased by $3.6&nbsp;million to $1,784.0&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $1,787.6&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015,
	primarily due to deferred financing costs of $12.7&nbsp;million paid in connection with our December 2015 issuance of our senior notes due 2025 and the amortization of premium on certain senior
	notes, partially offset by unamortized deferred financing costs of $7.5&nbsp;million expensed in connection with our December 2015 redemption of our senior notes due 2019 and amortization of
	deferred financing costs of $3.3&nbsp;million. Please see "Liquidity and Capital Resources" below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Deferred
	income tax liabilities increased by $28.8&nbsp;million to $114.7&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $85.9&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015 due primarily to
	the timing of recognition, for financial accounting purposes, of depreciation and amortization expenses compared to the timing of recognition of such expenses for income tax purposes. Please see
	Note&nbsp;16 of notes to consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Total
	stockholders' deficit decreased by $21.7&nbsp;million to $276.2&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $297.8&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30, 2015. This decrease was
	primarily a result of net earnings of $222.9&nbsp;million, and share-based compensation expense, the impact of exercises of stock options and other share-based compensation activity, in the
	aggregate, of approximately $28.4&nbsp;million. This decrease was partially offset by our repurchase and retirement of approximately 7.8&nbsp;million shares of our common stock for approximately
	$207.3&nbsp;million and foreign currency translation adjustments, net of tax, of $22.3&nbsp;million. Please see "Liquidity and Capital Resources" below.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We broadly define liquidity as our ability to generate sufficient cash flow from operating activities to meet our obligations and commitments. In addition,
	liquidity includes the ability to obtain appropriate debt and equity financing and to convert into cash those assets that are no longer required to meet existing strategic and financial objectives.
	Therefore, liquidity cannot be considered separately from capital resources that consist of current or potentially available funds for use in achieving long-range business objectives and meeting debt
	service commitments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	are highly leveraged and a substantial portion of our liquidity needs will arise from debt service on our outstanding indebtedness and from funding the costs of operations, working capital, capital
	expenditures and share repurchases. As a holding company, we depend on our subsidiaries, including Sally Holdings&nbsp;LLC (which we refer to as "Sally Holdings"), to distribute funds to us so that
	we may pay our obligations and expenses. The ability of our subsidiaries to make such distributions will be subject to their operating results, cash requirements and financial condition and their
	compliance with relevant laws, and covenants and financial ratios related to their existing or future indebtedness, including covenants restricting Sally Holdings' ability to pay dividends to us. If,
	as a consequence of these limitations, we cannot receive sufficient distributions from our subsidiaries, we may not be able to meet our obligations to fund general corporate expenses. Please see "Risk
	Factors&#151;Risks Relating to Our Business," and "&#151;Risks Relating to Our Substantial Indebtedness."
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	65
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=69,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=652238,FOLIO='65',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DQ10401A.;6',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='10-NOV-2016;19:31' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS10401_1_66">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"#000000" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:DOUBLE #000000 2.25PT;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:DOUBLE #000000 2.25PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;" -->
<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We may from time to time repurchase or otherwise retire or refinance our debt (through our subsidiaries or otherwise) and take other steps to reduce or refinance our debt.
	These actions may include open market repurchases of our notes or other retirements of outstanding debt. The amount of debt that may be repurchased, or refinanced or otherwise retired, if any, will be
	determined in the sole discretion of our Board of Directors and will depend on market conditions, trading levels of the Company's debt from time to time, the Company's cash position and other
	considerations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	September&nbsp;30, 2016, cash and cash equivalents were $86.6&nbsp;million. Based upon the current level of operations and anticipated growth, we anticipate that existing cash balances
	(excluding certain amounts permanently invested in connection with foreign operations), funds expected to be generated by operations and funds available under the ABL facility will be sufficient to
	meet our working capital requirements, fund share repurchases and potential acquisitions, and finance anticipated capital
	expenditures, including information technology upgrades and store remodels, over the next twelve months.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	However,
	there can be no assurance that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations, that anticipated net sales and operating improvements will be realized, or that future
	borrowings will be available under our ABL facility in an amount sufficient to enable us to service our indebtedness or to fund our other liquidity needs. In addition, our ability to meet our debt
	service obligations and liquidity needs are subject to certain risks, which include, but are not limited to, increases in competitive activity, the loss of key suppliers, rising interest rates, the
	loss of key personnel, the ability to execute our business strategy, general economic conditions and other risks discussed in this Annual Report. Please see "Risk Factors" in Item&nbsp;1A of this
	Annual Report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	utilize our ABL facility for the issuance of letters of credit, for certain working capital and liquidity needs and to manage normal fluctuations in our operational cash flow. In that regard, we
	may from time to time draw funds under the ABL facility for general corporate purposes including funding of capital expenditures, acquisitions, interest payments due on our indebtedness and share
	repurchases. The funds drawn on an individual occasion during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016 have varied in amounts up to $20.0&nbsp;million, total amounts outstanding have ranged
	from zero up to $90.0&nbsp;million and the average daily balance outstanding was $12.3&nbsp;million. During the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016, the weighted average interest rate on
	our borrowings under the ABL facility was 3.0%. The amounts drawn are generally paid down with cash provided by our operating activities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	of September&nbsp;30, 2016, there were no borrowings outstanding under the ABL facility and Sally Holdings had $478.4&nbsp;million available for borrowings under the ABL facility, subject to
	borrowing base limitations, as reduced by outstanding letters of credit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	are a holding company and do not have any material assets or operations other than ownership of equity interests in our subsidiaries. The agreements and instruments governing the debt of Sally
	Holdings and its subsidiaries contain material limitations on their ability to pay dividends and other restricted payments to us which, in turn, constitute material limitations on our ability to pay
	dividends and other payments to our stockholders. Please see "
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Long-Term Debt Covenants
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	" below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	During
	the fiscal years ended September&nbsp;30, 2016, 2015 and 2014 we completed several individually immaterial acquisitions at an aggregate cost of $26.1&nbsp;million, $7.1&nbsp;million and
	$4.9&nbsp;million, respectively. We generally funded these acquisitions with cash from operations, borrowings under the ABL facility and a portion of the cash proceeds from our October 2013 debt
	issuance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
<U>
	Share Repurchase Programs
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In August 2014, we announced that the Board had approved the 2014 Share Repurchase Program authorizing us to repurchase up to $1.0&nbsp;billion of our
	common stock over an approximate three-year period expiring on September&nbsp;30, 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	66
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=70,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=207438,FOLIO='66',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DS10401A.;12',USER='CHE109570',CD='11-NOV-2016;20:15' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS10401_1_67">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	During
	the fiscal years ended September&nbsp;30, 2016 and 2015, we repurchased and subsequently retired approximately 7.8&nbsp;million and 8.1&nbsp;million shares of our common stock,
	respectively, under the 2014 Share Repurchase Program at a cost of $207.3&nbsp;million and $227.6&nbsp;million, respectively. In addition, during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014,
	we repurchased and retired approximately 12.6&nbsp;million shares of our common stock under the 2013 Share Repurchase Program (a share repurchase program approved by our Board in March 2013 and
	terminated in connection with the authorization of the 2014 Share Repurchase Program) at a cost of $333.3&nbsp;million. We funded these share repurchases with cash from operations, borrowings under
	the ABL facility and a portion of the cash proceeds from our October 2013 debt issuance. Future repurchases of shares of our common stock are expected to be funded with existing cash balances, funds
	expected to be generated by operations and available borrowings under the ABL facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
<U>
	Historical Cash Flows
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For the fiscal years 2016, 2015 and 2014, our primary sources of cash have been funds provided by operating activities, our October 2013 debt issuance and,
	when necessary, borrowings under our ABL facility. The primary uses of cash during the past three years were for share repurchases, debt service, capital expenditures and acquisitions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>

	following table shows our sources and uses of funds for the fiscal years ended September&nbsp;30, 2016, 2015 and 2014 (in thousands):
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;
</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
	Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net cash provided by operating activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016 increased by $50.2&nbsp;million to $351.0&nbsp;million,
	compared to $300.8&nbsp;million during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 mainly due to an increase in net earnings before depreciation and amortization expenses, net loss on
	extinguishment of debt, share-based compensation, deferred income taxes, net loss on disposal of property and equipment and excess tax benefits resulting from share-based compensation activity (in the
	aggregate, $60.2&nbsp;million), partially offset by net changes in the components of working capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net
	cash provided by operating activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 decreased by $15.2&nbsp;million to $300.8&nbsp;million compared to $316.0&nbsp;million during the
	fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014, primarily due to a decrease in net earnings ($10.9&nbsp;million) and net changes in the components of working capital in the normal course of our
	business ($11.4&nbsp;million), partially offset by a change in
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	67
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=71,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=363339,FOLIO='67',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DS10401A.;12',USER='CHE109570',CD='11-NOV-2016;20:15' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS10401_1_68">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	depreciation
	and amortization expense ($9.7&nbsp;million). The changes in the components of working capital include net changes in operating assets ($49.3&nbsp;million), partially offset by net
	changes in operating liabilities ($37.8&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
	Net Cash Used by Investing Activities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net cash used by investing activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016 increased by $62.0&nbsp;million to $174.8&nbsp;million,
	compared to $112.8&nbsp;million during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015. This increase reflects incremental capital expenditures of $44.7&nbsp;million, primarily related to store
	openings and ongoing information technology upgrades in both business segments, store remodels in the Sally Beauty Supply segment (primarily in the U.S.) and upgrades to certain distribution centers
	and an increase of $19.7&nbsp;million in cash used for acquisitions, net of cash acquired, in the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30,
	2015, partially offset by incremental proceeds from sale of property and equipment ($2.3&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net
	cash used by investing activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015 increased by $31.1&nbsp;million to $112.8&nbsp;million compared to $81.8&nbsp;million during the
	fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This increase reflects an increase in capital expenditures ($29.7&nbsp;million) primarily related to store openings and to ongoing information technology
	upgrades in both business segments, and to store remodels in the Sally Beauty Supply segment in the U.S. during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, as well as an increase in cash used for
	acquisitions (net of cash acquired) of $1.3&nbsp;million during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
	Net Cash Used by Financing Activities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net cash used by financing activities increased by $77.1&nbsp;million to cash used of $229.0&nbsp;million during the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2016, compared to $152.0&nbsp;million during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, primarily due to the payment of a redemption premium ($25.8&nbsp;million) and
	debt issuance costs ($12.7&nbsp;million) in connection with our redemption of the senior notes due 2019 and issuance of the senior notes due 2025 in December 2015, and a decrease in proceeds from
	exercises of stock options and excess tax benefits resulting from share-based compensation activity, in the aggregate, of $58.9&nbsp;million, partially offset by a decrease in share repurchases
	under the 2014 Share Repurchase Program ($20.2&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net
	cash used by financing activities decreased by $21.8&nbsp;million to $152.0&nbsp;million during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2015, compared to $173.7&nbsp;million during the
	fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease in cash used to repurchase shares of our common stock of $105.7&nbsp;million, an increase in proceeds from
	exercises of stock options and excess tax benefits resulting from share-based compensation activity, in the aggregate, of $35.1&nbsp;million, and the impact of debt issuance costs of
	$3.9&nbsp;million paid in connection with issuance of the senior notes due 2023 in the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2014 with no comparable amount in the fiscal year ended
	September&nbsp;30, 2015, partially offset by a decrease in net borrowings under our long-term debt of $123.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
<U>
	Long-Term Debt
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
	Outstanding Long-Term Debt
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In November 2006, the Company, through its subsidiaries (Sally Investment Holdings&nbsp;LLC and Sally Holdings) incurred $1,850.0&nbsp;million of
	indebtedness in connection with the Company's separation from its former parent, Alberto-Culver.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	the fiscal year 2011, Sally Holdings entered into a $400&nbsp;million, five-year asset-based senior secured loan facility (the "ABL facility"). The availability of funds under the ABL facility,
	as amended in June 2012, is subject to a customary borrowing base comprised of: (i)&nbsp;a specified percentage of our eligible credit card
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	68
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=72,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=186249,FOLIO='68',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DS10401A.;12',USER='CHE109570',CD='11-NOV-2016;20:15' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS10401_1_69">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and
	trade accounts receivable (as defined therein) and (ii)&nbsp;a specified percentage of our eligible inventory (as defined therein), and reduced by (iii)&nbsp;certain customary reserves and
	adjustments and by certain outstanding letters of credit. The ABL facility includes a $25.0&nbsp;million Canadian sub-facility for our Canadian operations. In the fiscal year 2013, the Company,
	Sally Holdings and other parties to the ABL facility entered into a second amendment to the ABL facility which, among other things, increased the maximum availability under the ABL Facility to
	$500.0&nbsp;million (subject to borrowing base limitations), reduced pricing, relaxed the restrictions regarding the making of Restricted Payments, extended the maturity to July 2018 and improved
	certain other covenant terms. At September&nbsp;30, 2016, the Company had $478.4&nbsp;million available for borrowing under the ABL facility, including the Canadian sub-facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	the fiscal year 2012, Sally Holdings and Sally Capital&nbsp;Inc. (collectively, the "Issuers"), both indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries of the Company, issued $750.0&nbsp;million aggregate
	principal amount of their 6.875% Senior Notes due 2019 (the "senior notes due 2019") and $850.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of their 5.75% Senior Notes due 2022 (the "senior notes due
	2022"), including $150.0&nbsp;million of the aggregate principal amount of the senior notes due 2022 issued at par plus a premium. Such premium is being amortized over the term of the senior notes
	due 2022 using the effective interest method. The net proceeds from these debt issuances were used to retire outstanding indebtedness in the aggregate principal amount of approximately
	$1,391.9&nbsp;million (substantially all of which was incurred in 2006 in connection with our separation from Alberto-Culver) and for general corporate purposes. In December 2015, the Company
	redeemed in full the senior notes due 2019 at a redemption premium equal to 103.438% primarily with the net proceeds from the issuance of the 5.625% Senior Notes due 2025 (the "senior notes due
	2025"), as further discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	the fiscal year 2014, the Issuers issued $200.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of their 5.5% Senior Notes due 2023 (the "senior notes due 2023") at par. The Company used the net proceeds
	from this debt issuance, approximately $196.3&nbsp;million, to repay borrowings outstanding under the ABL facility of $88.5&nbsp;million (which borrowings were primarily used to fund share
	repurchases) and for general corporate purposes, including share repurchases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	December&nbsp;3, 2015, the Issuers issued $750.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of their senior notes due 2025 at par. The Company used the net proceeds from this debt issuance
	(approximately $737.3&nbsp;million), as well as existing cash balances, to redeem in full the senior notes due 2019, at a total redemption cost of $775.8&nbsp;million, excluding accrued interest.
	In connection with our redemption of the senior notes due 2019, we recorded a loss on extinguishment of debt in the amount of approximately $33.3&nbsp;million, including a redemption premium in the
	amount of approximately $25.8&nbsp;million and unamortized deferred financing costs of approximately $7.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	of September&nbsp;30, 2016, the principal amount of long-term debt (excluding capitalized leases) is as follows (dollars in thousands):
</FONT>
</P>

<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Amounts
	reported above do not reflect unamortized premium of $5.6&nbsp;million related to notes with an aggregate principal amount of $150.0&nbsp;million or
	unamortized debt issuance costs in the aggregate amount of $23.7&nbsp;million, at September&nbsp;30, 2016.
</FONT>

</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:10PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Making of
	acquisitions
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;">
<P ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-12PT;MARGIN-LEFT:0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_GRID,"TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:10PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Mergers or
	consolidations
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

<TD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;">
<P ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-12PT;MARGIN-LEFT:0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_GRID,"TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:10PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Disposition of
	assets
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Borrowings
	under the ABL facility are secured by the accounts, inventory and credit card receivables (and related general intangibles and other property) of our domestic subsidiaries (and, in the case
	of borrowings under the Canadian sub-facility, such assets of our Canadian subsidiaries and, solely with respect to borrowings by SBH Finance&nbsp;B.V., intercompany notes owed to SBH
	Finance&nbsp;B.V. by our foreign subsidiaries). The senior notes due 2022, the senior notes due 2023 and the senior notes due 2025 (which we refer to collectively as "the Senior Notes" or the
	"senior notes due 2022, 2023 and 2025") are unsecured obligations of the Issuers and are jointly and severally guaranteed by the Company and Sally Investment, and by each material domestic subsidiary
	of the Company. Interest on the senior notes due 2022, 2023 and 2025 is payable semi-annually, during the Company's first and third fiscal quarters.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	ABL facility and the indentures governing the senior notes due 2022, 2023 and 2025 contain other covenants regarding restrictions on asset dispositions, granting of liens and security interests,
	prepayment of certain indebtedness and other matters and customary events of default, including customary cross-default and/or cross-acceleration provisions. As of September&nbsp;30, 2016, all the
	net assets of our consolidated subsidiaries were unrestricted from transfer under our credit arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	senior notes due 2022 carry optional redemption features whereby the Company has the option to redeem the notes, in whole or in part, on or after June&nbsp;1, 2020 at par, plus accrued and
	unpaid interest, if any, and on or after June&nbsp;1, 2017 at par plus a premium declining ratably to par, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any. Prior to June&nbsp;1, 2017, the notes may be
	redeemed, in whole or in part, at a
	redemption price equal to par plus a make-whole premium as provided in the indenture, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	senior notes due 2023 carry optional redemption features whereby the Company has the option to redeem the notes, in whole or in part, on or after November&nbsp;1, 2021 at par, plus accrued and
	unpaid interest, if any, and on or after November&nbsp;1, 2018 at par plus a premium declining ratably to par, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any. Prior to November&nbsp;1, 2018, the notes
	may be redeemed, in whole or in part, at a redemption price equal to par plus a make-whole premium as provided in the indenture, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	senior notes due 2025 carry optional redemption features whereby the Company has the option to redeem the notes, in whole or in part, on or after December&nbsp;1, 2023 at par, plus accrued and
	unpaid interest, if any, and on or after December&nbsp;1, 2020 at par plus a premium declining ratably to par, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any. Prior to December&nbsp;1, 2020, the notes
	may be redeemed, in whole or in part, at a redemption price equal to par plus a make-whole premium as provided in the indenture, plus
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	70
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=74,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=82901,FOLIO='70',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DS10401A.;12',USER='CHE109570',CD='11-NOV-2016;20:15' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS10401_1_71">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	accrued
	and unpaid interest, if any. In addition, on or prior to December&nbsp;1, 2018, the Company has the right to redeem at par plus a specified premium, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any,
	up to 35% of the aggregate principal amount of notes originally issued, subject to certain limitations, with the proceeds from certain kinds of equity offerings, as defined in the indenture.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	ABL facility does not contain any restriction against the incurrence of unsecured indebtedness. However, the ABL facility restricts the incurrence of secured indebtedness if, after giving effect
	to the incurrence of such secured indebtedness, the Company's Secured Leverage Ratio exceeds 4.0 to 1.0. At September&nbsp;30, 2016, the Company's Secured Leverage Ratio was less than 0.1
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.0.
	Secured Leverage Ratio is defined as the ratio of (i)&nbsp;Secured Funded Indebtedness (as defined in the ABL facility) to
	(ii)&nbsp;Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the ABL facility) for the most recently completed twelve fiscal months.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	ABL facility is pre-payable and the commitments thereunder may be terminated, in whole or in part at any time without penalty or premium.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	indentures governing the senior notes due 2022, 2023 and 2025 contain terms which restrict the ability of Sally Beauty's subsidiaries to incur additional indebtedness. However, in addition to
	certain other material exceptions, the Company may incur additional indebtedness under the indentures if its
	Consolidated Coverage Ratio, after giving pro forma effect to the incurrence of such indebtedness, exceeds 2.0
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.0 ("Incurrence Test"). At
	September&nbsp;30, 2016, the Company's Consolidated Coverage Ratio was approximately 6.1
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.0. Consolidated Coverage Ratio is defined as the ratio
	of (i)&nbsp;Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the indentures) for the period containing the most recent four consecutive fiscal quarters,
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(ii)&nbsp;Consolidated Interest Expense (as defined in the indentures) for such period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	indentures governing the Senior Notes restrict Sally Holdings and its subsidiaries from making certain dividends and distributions to equity holders and certain other restricted payments
	(hereafter, a "Restricted Payment" or "Restricted Payments") to us. However, the indentures permit the making of such Restricted Payments if, at the time of the making of such Restricted Payment, the
	Company satisfies the Incurrence Test as described above and the cumulative amount of all Restricted Payments made since the issue date of the applicable senior notes does not exceed the sum of:
	(i)&nbsp;50% of Sally Holdings' and its subsidiaries' cumulative consolidated net earnings since July&nbsp;1, 2006 (for the senior notes due 2022 and the senior notes due 2023) or since
	October&nbsp;1, 2015 (for the senior notes due 2025),
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	plus
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(ii)&nbsp;the proceeds from the issuance of certain equity securities or conversions of
	indebtedness to equity, in each case, since the issue date of the applicable senior notes
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	plus
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(iii)&nbsp;the net reduction in investments in
	unrestricted subsidiaries since the issue date of the applicable senior notes
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	plus
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(iv)&nbsp;the return of capital with respect to any sales or
	dispositions of certain minority investments since the issue date of the applicable senior notes
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	plus
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(v)&nbsp;$350&nbsp;million (for the senior
	notes due 2025). Further, in addition to certain other baskets, the indentures permit the Company to make additional Restricted Payments in an unlimited amount if, after giving pro forma effect to the
	incurrence of any indebtedness to make such Restricted Payment, the Company's Consolidated Total Leverage Ratio (as defined in the indentures) is less than 3.25
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.00. At September&nbsp;30, 2016, the
	Company's Consolidated Total Leverage Ratio was approximately 2.7
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.0. Consolidated Total Leverage Ratio is defined as the ratio of (i)&nbsp;Consolidated Total Indebtedness, as defined in the
	indentures,
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	minus
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	cash and cash equivalents on-hand up to $100.0&nbsp;million, in each case, as of the end of the most recently-ended fiscal quarter
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	to
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(ii)&nbsp;Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the indentures) for the period containing the most recent four consecutive fiscal quarters.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	ABL facility also restricts the making of Restricted Payments. More specifically, under the ABL facility, Sally Holdings may make Restricted Payments if availability under the ABL facility equals
	or exceeds certain thresholds, and no default then exists under the facility. For Restricted Payments up to $30.0&nbsp;million during each fiscal year, borrowing availability must equal or exceed
	the lesser of $75.0&nbsp;million or 15% of the borrowing base for 45&nbsp;days prior to such Restricted Payment. For Restricted Payments in excess of that amount, borrowing availability must equal
	or exceed the lesser of $100.0&nbsp;million or 20% of
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	71
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=75,EFW="2230256",CP="SALLY BEAUTY HOLDINGS, INC.",DN="1",CHK=386289,FOLIO='71',FILE='DISK134:[16ZCE1.16ZCE10401]DS10401A.;12',USER='CHE109570',CD='11-NOV-2016;20:15' -->
<A NAME="A2230256Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS10401_1_72">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2230256Z10-K_HTM_BG10401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	borrowing base for 45&nbsp;days prior to such Restricted Payment and the Consolidated Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio (as defined below) must equal or exceed 1.1 to 1.0. Further, if borrowing
	availability equals or exceeds the lesser of $150.0&nbsp;million or 30% of the borrowing base, Restricted Payments are not limited by the Consolidated Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio test. The
	Consolidated Fixed Charge
	Coverage Ratio is defined as the ratio of (i)&nbsp;Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the ABL facility) during the trailing twelve-month period preceding such proposed Restricted Payment minus
	certain unfinanced capital expenditures made during such period and income tax payments paid in cash during such period to (ii)&nbsp;fixed charges (as defined in the ABL facility). In addition,
	during any period that borrowing availability under the ABL facility is less than the greater of $40.0&nbsp;million or 10% of the borrowing base, the level of the Consolidated Fixed Charge Coverage
	Ratio that the Company must satisfy is 1.0 to 1.0. As of September&nbsp;30, 2016, the Consolidated Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio was approximately 3.1 to 1.0.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	When
	used in this Annual Report, the phrase "Consolidated EBITDA" is intended to have the meaning ascribed to such phrase in the ABL facility or the indentures governing the senior notes due 2022,
	2023 and 2025, as appropriate. EBITDA is not a recognized measurement under accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ("GAAP") and should not be considered a substitute
	for financial performance and liquidity measures determined in accordance with GAAP, such as net earnings, operating earnings and operating cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	are currently in compliance with the agreements and instruments governing our debt, including our financial covenants. Our ability to comply with these covenants in future periods will depend on
	our ongoing financial and operating performance, which in turn will be subject to economic conditions and to financial, market and competitive factors, many of which are beyond our control. Further,
	our ability to comply with these covenants in future periods will also depend substantially on the pricing of our products, our success at implementing cost reduction initiatives and our ability to
	successfully implement our overall business strategy. Please see "Risk Factors&#151;Risks Relating to Our Substantial Indebtedness."
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
<U>
	Capital Requirements
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	During the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2016, we had total capital expenditures of approximately $143.4&nbsp;million, including amounts incurred
	but not paid at September&nbsp;30, 2016 (approximately $3.8&nbsp;million), which were primarily in connection with the addition of new stores and store remodels, expansion or relocation of
	existing stores in the ordinary course of our business, upgrades to certain distribution centers in the U.S. and ongoing information technology upgrades. For the fiscal year 2017, we anticipate
	capital expenditures of approximately $135.0&nbsp;million, excluding acquisitions. Capital expenditures will be primarily to fund the addition of new stores, store remodels, upgrades to our
	distribution centers in the U.S., expansion or relocation of existing stores, as well as certain corporate projects in the ordinary course of our business, including ongoing technology upgrades.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	72
</FONT>
</P>

	&#8203;
